SRP.Q: What is the vertical (above/below) relationship of the area representing Luxury Consumers relative to Subscription Members?
SRP.A: Luxury Consumers is {below} Subscription Members in the vertical direction.

VPR.Q: Which series contributes the largest portion to the total online sales volume?
VPR.A: The series with the largest contribution is {Subscription Members}.

VPR.Q: Which series contributes the smallest portion to the total online sales volume?
VPR.A: The series with the smallest contribution is {Millennials}.

NC.Q: Between 2007 and 2019, was the average total Online Sales Volume higher or lower than between 2004 and 2008?
NC.A: The average total online sales volume between 2007 and 2019 was {higher} than between 2004 and 2008.

NC.Q: Was the total Online Sales Volume in 2004 higher or lower than in 2013?
NC.A: The total online sales volume in 2004 was {lower} than in 2013.

NC.Q: Between 2004 and 2019, did the total Online Sales Volume experience a larger or smaller change than between 2010 and 2016?
NC.A: The change in total online sales volume between 2004 and 2019 was {larger} than between 2010 and 2016.

NC.Q: Between 2006 and 2012, did the total Online Sales Volume experience a larger or smaller change than between 2011 and 2017?
NC.A: The change in total online sales volume between 2006 and 2012 was {smaller} than between 2011 and 2017.

MSR.Q: Which series has the largest cumulative area in this area chart?
MSR.A: {Subscription Members} has the largest cumulative area.

VA.Q: To reduce the 'waving' visual effect in the area chart, reorder the layers by end value and list the labels from top to bottom after sorting.
VA.A: The reordered layer order from top to bottom is: {Millennials, Urban Shoppers, Rural Buyers, International Customers, Budget Shoppers, Subscription Members, Luxury Consumers}.
